pros: The co-worker I've had have been great IF you are a student and work Full time, the 50% tuition discount is great.
cons: As you'll see with most of the reviews, the pay and the benefits are indeed very low and could be improved. I can also confirm what a previous reviewer said "On several occasions, the CEO has bragged about how amazing the ministry is doing financially, but not to get your hopes up for any raises anytime soon". I think there is the attitude that people will work for the ministry without zero regard for salary and that leads to bare minimum wages in many departments. While the ministry pays lip service to relationship/people focused management, (even having us watch videos by Dean Radtke about healthy management) many departments at the ministry still follow the usual Command and Control or Soldier styles of leadership that the Secular corporate world uses. They can't make up their mind if they wanna operate like a ministry or a corporation. They lean the ministry way when it's convenient to get people to not bring up complaints, but when it comes to how they handle people they're often colder than the corporate world. Usually the squeaky wheel gets the grease, in the departments I've worked in, the squeaky wheel get told to suck it up and get in line (in the name of Biblical submission) or leave. Leadership appears to ultimately makes decisions based on numbers and effecency with little regard to the impact it will have on staff. They're bleeding talent because of burnout and leadership is oblivious to what needs to be done to improve staff morale. Until they learn to truly value their staff, many departments will continue to hemorrhage people. Disclaimer: I don't put any of these issues on Andrew himself, I believe the issue is further down the chain of leadership. I also understand that not all the departments function this way but the two departments I have experience with both treated people as expendable.

review_title: Excellent place to work and grow
job_title: Intranet Manager in Woodland Park, CO
pros: Excellent workplace, leadership, and growth focused environment! Highly recommend AWM for any Christian looking to have an impact on the world alongside great people in a growing ministry.
cons: If working on-site, it is located in a mountainous region.

job_title: Accounting Specialist in Woodland Park, CO
pros: Beautiful scenery and location of the home office
cons: its not run like a true ministry.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Woodland Park, CO
pros: The people you work with are amazing. I truly love the peers that I work with. They are knowledgeable, caring and fun. Even the people who can be difficult to work with, outside of work tend to be amazing.
cons:
Where to start. Ok, we’ll I need to start somewhere. The pay and the benefits are very low. Their idea of encouraging the staff is sending a company wide email to the effect of, “We spent a truck ton of money to improve our building! Aren’t you happy you get to work here!” On several occasions, the CEO has bragged about how amazing the ministry is doing financially, but not to get your hopes up for any raises anytime soon. 

These to me are minor annoyances. The heart of my 1 star rating comes to how this ministry operates as a whole. They preach innovation, to be creative, take responsibility for yourself and your team. But when the rubber hits the road it is a micromanaged nightmare. They stifle ideas that do not come down from the top. I could go on and on, and it really breaks my heart because I love this ministry and what they do! I cannot in good conscience advise anyone to come work here unless you feel specifically called!

review_title: Great place to give you an opportunity to enter the field
job_title: Software Development Manager in Woodland Park, CO
pros:
They will most likely give you a chance, and they are all good people.
Lots of opportunity for growth if you apply yourself correctly.
cons:
The company's pay rates falls below the competitive market value, with very few benefits and incentives. 
Some would say that's to be expected when working for a non-profit company.

review_title: Blessed place to work and serve

review_title: Best Place in the World to Work
job_title: Technician II in Woodland Park, CO
pros: Excellent coworkers, positive work environment, everything you do at your job is to benefit and help others, great training and support, surrounding community is wonderful, employers actually care about you, supervisors/managers are all for you succeeding in what God has for you.
cons: Pay is slightly lower than average but it’s a good compromise for the environment you’re in and work you get to do, sometimes long days during conferences (but you get overtime pay or you can take days off following conferences).

job_title: Prayer Minister in Woodland Park, CO
pros: Great experience praying for people
cons: Micromanaged. Your just a body.

pros: You get to help people realize their created value and pray for them.
cons: None that I can think of!

pros: It was such a treat to work for such an amazing no place!!!
cons: not applicable for this section

review_title: Great people who are in over their heads
pros: Most everyone is nice and you are working towards something important, thats really about it. Commute sucks from the springs, benefits aren't much, pay is below average.
cons: Organization and communication is terrible. Worker appreciation is terrible (though I've heard some departments are better than others) Here a hint talk is cheap you can say "thanks" and "we appreciate you" till you're blue in the face but if you constantly let employees down where it matters youre talk means nothing.

review_title: Intentional Organization that Disciples and Develops It's Employees
job_title: Phone Center Minister in Woodland Park, CO
pros:
- If you work hard and want to grow there are always opportunities to do so
- you get to be part of a tremendously valuable mission (spreading the Gospel)
- coworkers and managers truly care about you as a person
- I've learned and grown so much as an employee during my time at this organization.
cons:
- You will be paid at a non-profit level. Many of the positions types are higher paid at for-profit organizations
- It's an extremely values-driven organization. If you don't agree with the organizations' key values you will find the organization's goals and culture harder to relate to. I actually think this is usually a plus. I would rather be part of an organization that has clear values and a clear goals than one that just wants to make money.

pros: I've worked at this ministry for a few years and I can honestly say that the founder Andrew Wommack is the same behind close doors and he is on TV or speaking at a conference.  He's very well known but he's down to earth and a great leader.
cons: Every ministry I've been around has their issues.  This one is no different.  Work here because you believe you're supposed to not because you have to or need to.  That will save you a lot of heart ache.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great people that work there.
cons: HR does not protect employees but rather the company.  A lot of good meaning people but so many ego battles that cause dysfunction.  Andrew stays too unaware of what is going on in the breadth of the ministry and only listens to his top people who are the ones who skew everything.

review_title: Small organization mindset running large organization
pros: The vision of helping others in ministry is its strength. If you believe in ministry and are eager to be a part of something touching the world, this ministry offers that.
cons: It grew too fast, and so it doesn't have a good infrastructure. High turnover in many departments. Mom and Pop mentality in management - lots of chaos and miscommunication. Several departments are very unprofessional.

review_title: What you do everyday has an impact on people around the world.
pros: You help people.  You are around people that care about each other and are there to help when you are in need.
cons: Health care is expensive but that is pretty normal everywhere you go.  Pay is average.

pros: Benefits options are ok. The work/life balance is awesome.  Managers are always willing to hear what you have to say.  The work schedules are very flexible, and a guaranteed 40 hr. work week.  Great PTO, and time off with family.  Has a very strong sense of work family here as well.
cons: Pay is moderate to low for this kind of position.  The cost of benefits for anything other than single person is ridiculously high.

review_title: You'll think better of this organization if you never work for them
job_title: Enterprise Chain Manager in Woodland Park, CO
pros: They do believe in Jesus Christ and the amazing things He has done and is doing for us today.
cons: Favoritism, you don't have to be qualified for your job.  You just have to know the right people.

review_title: My experience at Andrew Wommack Ministeries has been life changing.
pros: Being able to offer counsel, encouragement and guidance by way of prayer to others. This has impacted my life by me becoming more compassionate . It is an honor to work for a company that really have a heart to  express the value of others.
cons: Being a part-time employer it does not offer any paid vacation

job_title: Video Producer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Excellent teaching ministry and healthy christian environment to work in. Good PTO and flexibility to work remotely.
cons: Internal restructure happens often and no career paths established unless you are working in the phone center. Pay is low. No performance reviews so there is no way to know if there are any raises available.

job_title: Closed Caption-er in Woodland Park, CO
pros: Andrew Wommack is the same on stage and off. He is very loving and wants the best for his employees. Depending on what department you are in, there will be lots of room for growth.
cons: As with most ministries, the pay is lower.
